_exec_summary.SummaryText:
California Dairies, Inc. revised this document from April thru November of 2012 as a part of the 5-year update as required for Risk Management Programs and good practice. This Risk Management Program was initially created in November of 2007.

California Dairies, Inc. Visalia prepared a Chemical Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management Program (RMP/PSM) in general accordance with state and federal regulations. The state risk management regulations, also referred to as the California Accidental Release
Prevention (CalARP) program, are codified in the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Section 2735.1,
et. Seq. 

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also regulates facilities with certain toxic and flammable
substances to comply. The regulations are codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. Finally,
both the Occupational Safety and Health Association (OSHA) and the California Occupational Safety and
Health Association (CalOSHA) regulate facilities with certain acutely hazardous materials under the PSM
regulations, as defined in CCR Title 8, Section 5189 and CFR Title 29, Part 1910, Section 119, respectively.

SCOPE
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted
to the EPA. The following areas are addressed in this summary:

¿_Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
¿_Stationary Source Activities and Regulated Substances Handled
¿_Worst-Case and Alternative-Case Release Scenarios
¿_Prevention Program
¿_Five-Year Accident History
¿_Emergency Response Program
¿_Planned Changes to Improve Safety

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
California Dairies is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk
Management Program. California Dairies has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety
Management (RMP/PSM) Manuals to document policies/proce

dures and address the implementation of these regulations.
The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis
study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP
sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis)
Report.

Reporting and Action: Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.
State regulations require reporting when there is a  substantial accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental
release of ammonia. California Dairies interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury
above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms. All releases are to be
monitored and all readings recorded. All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop or correct procedures
that may prevent future incidents.

Any release of more than 25 ppm may result in immediately shutting down the ammonia system depending on
the location of the release. The General Manager and Maintenance are to be called if not on site for support.
Releases less than 25 PPM shall result in immediately calling the General Manager and Maintenance, if not on
site, for instructions.

There are additional full time supervisory and operational employees at this facility in addition to the
Maintenance Supervisor that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia
system on a regular basis during daily rounds and walks. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release
immediately. An example would be excessive rust on piping or tanks, odor, noise or vibration. This team activity is the core of California
Dairies prevention program.

STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLE

D
The California Dairies facility provides production, product cooling, and short-term storage of dairy products.
The facility is located in an industrial area of Tulare County on a contiguous property. Ammonia is used as the
refrigerant in the Main Plant Refrigeration System. The total ammonia inventory in the Main Plant system
exceeds the Federal and State thresholds.

The refrigeration system is a combination of a direct, closed loop, and secondary coolant mechanical refrigeration system. The original process was built in 2007. The ammonia equipment is located outside, in a machinery room and in a cooler/freezer.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel
or pipe. As this system has interconnected piping and since the largest vessel can hold the complete charge the total system charge was used for the worst case scenario.

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this
scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition the
Main Plant System is separated by walls and distance. Furthermore as the refrigerant escapes pressure will
decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide
uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.
The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
California Dairies Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM (CalARP) Manual. The RMP Prevention
Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program
implemented by California Dairies is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of California Dairies Prevention Program are briefly described below:
1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system techni

cal information. (Addressed under the Process
Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system. The evaluation considers a number of
potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes). All
safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by California Dairies. (Addressed
under Process Hazard Analysis and Mechanical Integrity Elements).

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and
maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical
Integrity, and Incident Investigation Elements.)

4) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system. California Dairies certifies
operators following completion of operator training and California Dairies confirmation of the operator's ability to
apply what they have learned. (Addressed under Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program. This is addressed on two levels. First, refrigeration
equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process
Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).
This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-today
activities.

Second, all California Dairies employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness
training. Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information. These activities improve the overall
safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation Element)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical). These
measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator t

raining,
and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by California Dairies Management of
Change Procedure.

If a mechanical change is required and for maintenance contracts, California Dairies has a procedure for
selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding,
or other "Hot Work" occurs close to the refrigeration system, a California Dairies Hot Work permit is required.
The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire.
Following completion of a mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be
started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Contractor Qualifications, Hot Work
Permit, and Pre-Start-up Safety Review Elements.)

7) Verification of California Dairies compliance with the RMP/PSM program. This self-audit process is an
important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program (and the Risk Management
Program) has been implemented and properly documented by California Dairies. California Dairies has(Addressed under Compliance Audit chapter.)

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under California Dairies Injury and Illness Prevention
Program)

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the standard of
State or Federal regulations.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response Plan developed for this facility.
Responders are trained to enter an IDLH condition. Responders are also trained to the (300 PPM) Air Purifying
Respirator level. Responders will assist outside agencies during larger releases.

Detailed plans (emergency action plans) have been developed to assist responding facility personnel. All areas
(zones) inside the building can be brought under control within 20

minutes of any ammonia emergency or
breakdown if personnel are on site. Small releases can be brought under control immediately.

The emergency release response plan for all releases is to gain access to the shutdown valves and switches/controls
for the component or area with the release. If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire
ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate. The appropriate shut down switches are identified.

The Federal and California Emergency Planning Regulations considered in this program include:
_EPA's Risk Management Plan
_OSHA's Emergency Action Plan
_OSHA's Process Safety Standard
_EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know
_Contingency Plan
_Hazardous Materials Plan (HMBP)

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility. The
prevention program has been updated as required on an ongoing basis and to satisfy the 5 yr. update. 

A PHA study, compliance audit and mechanical integrity audit were conducted during the 2001 and 2012 calendar years. The study team made recommendations for additional safety.

The following is an overview of planned changes.

"Trip high levels annually. Add this task to your PM Program
preventative maintenance and inspection
program."



"Dedicate ladder to area and consider drop
chains and wheels on critical valves."

"Assure fan blades and motor mounts are 
secure and mechanically sound during annually"

Repair Insulation where damaged.

"Consider installing signage or a type of warning 
under the south two cooler evaporators."

"Consider upgrading and networking controls to
provide remote monitoring of failures and
safeties."

"Verify the facility is enforcing a meet and greet
policy."

Include an updated close receptor call list in the 5 Yr. Update.

"Consider increasing drills and training of
response team."

"Verify continuous

fans shut down during 
emergency fan activation."

"Recommend installing (AMMONIA
EVACUATION ALARM) sign at horns and lights.
Or similar"

"Recommend coordination and practice with
outside parties for 2013. Obtain citric powder
and applicator (liquid spray) for neutralization."

"Complete valve tagging and pipe labeling. 
Replace incorrect labels in engine room.
Replace missing valve tags at ammonia pump."

"Add 3 year valve maintenance to your
preventative maintenance and inspection
program."

"Add cleaning and painting of piping and 
equipment to your preventive maintenance
program. Repair damaged insulation. Add
corrosion prevention program."

"Recommend installing catwalks and access to 
top of condensers on at least 2 sides to increase
safety and elevate level of maintenance."

"Verify setpoint list is current. Correct if 
necessary. Recommend posting at control
system or compressor microprocessors."
